itemDescription: politician and public servant in New South Wales, Australia

wikipedia_page.main: Hugh Langwell (1860 – 15 May 1933) was an Irish-born politician, trade unionist and public servant in New South Wales, Australia. He was a member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly, Legislative Council, Amalgamated Shearers Union, Western Lands Board and Lord Howe Island Board of Control.

response: The Western Lands Act 1901  established a Western Lands Board, composed of three commissioners, to issue leases in the Western Division. The  See government appointed Colin James McMasters as chairman on a salary of £1,500 per year and Robert McDonald and Hugh Langwell as commissioners on a salary of £1,000 per year. In 1931 the Lang government appointed a Royal Commission to inquire into the administration of the Western Lands Division, including whether the then commissioners, Hugh Langwell, George Australia Denning and Arthur Willim Mullen were guilty of misbehaviour or incompetence. The commissioner, Ernest Arthur Prior, found that they had been negligent and incompetent, and they were dismissed on the advice of cabinet.

link_mentions.page: Candidates of the 1894 New South Wales colonial election
response: |Bourke || William Davis || |Edward Millen || || Hugh Langwell (Ind Lab)

link_mentions.page: Candidates of the 1891 New South Wales colonial election
response: |Bourke || 3 Protectionist || |William Davis  Peter Howe*  Austin O'Grady  Thomas Waddell  William Willis* || Edward Millen || || |Hugh Langwell* (Ind Lab)

link_mentions.page: Results of the 1894 New South Wales colonial election
response: Bourke was reduced in size and parts were given to the new districts of Cobar and The Barwon. Hugh Langwell (Independent Labour) was one of the members for Bourke. Of the other two members, Thomas Waddell (Protectionist) successfully contested Cobar and William Willis (Protectionist) successfully contested The Barwon.
